metadata.h1: 3 Rules For Dashboards People Actually Look At

all_paragraphs: I’ve been asked to create dashboards for several companies over my career. To my surprise, a marketing team at one of the biggest technology corporations in the world asked my team to develop dashboards for them. I assumed that big tech companies had all these things figured out. This company, in particular, had an entire department dedicated to marketing analytics and measurement and had hundreds of dashboards at their disposal.
The problem was, nobody used any of them.

When I finally got a look at the dashboards that the team had in place, It wasn’t hard to figure out why. Nobody used the dashboards because nobody in the business understood what they were looking at. Mind you, these were some of the most beautiful, sophisticated dashboards I have ever seen — they were filled with dozens of KPIs, advanced charts, statistics, gauges, and tables. These were dashboards built to the highest degree of technical proficiency and analytics prowess, but they failed to solve the problem that they were supposed to be solving for: Provide actionable information to the business.

Don’t get caught in the common trap that complexity = sophistication. Doing more is definitely not always better. This quote, from Leonardo Davinci (supposedly), is one I actually believe in: “Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.” Follow this creed with your dashboards (and pretty much everything you do). If the business user can’t understand clearly the value that the dashboard gives back to them, they’ll never look at it. It needs to be so simple and easy to use and look at that the business user can’t run their business without it.

Unfortunately, even folks on the business side can be blinded by really pretty looking charts and graphs — you might have even been praised by the business for a dashboard you’ve built that was extremely sophisticated. But that expression of approval is just the business recognizing your technical skills, not the satisfaction that you solved their problem. At first glance, they’ll think you’ve solved their problem because of how amazing everything looks. But without even thinking, they’ll be back to pivot tables and manual data pulls within a month.

The allure of putting huge amounts of information on your dashboards is part of an overarching desire for data analysis — business users want insights to make them better at doing their jobs. The problem is, dashboards are one of the worst tools for data analysis. They’re not designed for answering deep questions about your data — but they’re fantastic for tracking and measurement.

Develop your dashboards with an eye towards metrics that can be a) tracked over-time and b) measured against something. Don’t just visualize the numbers, compare them against a target, a historical timeline, or a competing product. The visualization must not only answer the question of “what?” and “when?” but “compared to what?”
3) Dashboards should measure what matters, not what's easy.

Jobs Theory teaches not only a framework for how to innovate but how to build your organization around “jobs to be done” and identify metrics that matter. Dr. Clayton Christensen, the creator of Jobs Theory, called these metrics “customer benefit metrics” — in other words, the metrics that indicate how well you’re product or service solve the job that it was designed to solve (Competing Against Luck, p.161). Unfortunately, the data behind “customer benefit metrics” are typically incredibly hard to gather. Subsequently, as analytics professionals and data scientists, we default to the data that is easiest to get to and most readily available. In an effort to feel like we’re accomplishing something, we pull in, pivot, and analyze these hundreds of data sources, creating complex models and amazing visualizations that, while beautiful to look at, and demonstrate our technical skill, ultimately fall short of the goal — which is to provide the business with the most important and valuable information possible.

Spend less time making dashboard widgets, fancy charts, or creating new data pipelines and more time defining your most important KPIs. Then, create strategies to get the data that truly matters to your business.
